trans-unit.source: Protect VMs from one VMM site to another with PowerShell and Microsoft Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Protect VMs from one VMM site to another with PowerShell and Microsoft Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: Automate protection between two on-premises VMM site and Azure using PowerShell and Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Automate protection between two on-premises VMM site and Azure using PowerShell and Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: VMM site to VMM site with PowerShell and Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: VMM site to VMM site with PowerShell and Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Azure Site Recovery contributes to your business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) strategy by orchestrating replication, failover and recovery of virtual machines in a number of deployment scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Azure Site Recovery contributes to your business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) strategy by orchestrating replication, failover and recovery of virtual machines in a number of deployment scenarios.

trans-unit.source: For a full list of deployment scenarios see the <link><linkText>Azure Site Recovery overview</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For a full list of deployment scenarios see the <link><linkText>Azure Site Recovery overview</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: It can work with two types of modules - the Azure Profile module, or the Azure Resource Manager (ARM) module.
trans-unit.target: It can work with two types of modules - the Azure Profile module, or the Azure Resource Manager (ARM) module.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to use Windows PowerShell® together with ARM to deploy Azure Site Recovery to configure and orchestrate virtual machine protection between two VMM sites.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to use Windows PowerShell® together with ARM to deploy Azure Site Recovery to configure and orchestrate virtual machine protection between two VMM sites.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines running on Hyper-V host servers that are located in VMM private clouds in a primary site will replicate and fail over to a secondary VMM site using Hyper-V Replica.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines running on Hyper-V host servers that are located in VMM private clouds in a primary site will replicate and fail over to a secondary VMM site using Hyper-V Replica.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to be a PowerShell expert to use this article, but it does assume that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.
trans-unit.target: You don't need to be a PowerShell expert to use this article, but it does assume that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see <link><linkText>Getting Started with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see <link><linkText>Getting Started with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Read more about <link><linkText>Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Read more about <link><linkText>Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The article includes prerequisites for the scenario, and shows you how to set up Azure PowerShell to work with Site Recovery, create a Site Recovery vault, install the Azure Site Recovery Provider on VMM servers and register them vault, configure protection settings for VMM clouds that will be applied to all protected virtual machines, and then enable protection for those virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: The article includes prerequisites for the scenario, and shows you how to set up Azure PowerShell to work with Site Recovery, create a Site Recovery vault, install the Azure Site Recovery Provider on VMM servers and register them vault, configure protection settings for VMM clouds that will be applied to all protected virtual machines, and then enable protection for those virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: You'll finish up by testing the failover to make sure everything's working as expected.
trans-unit.target: You'll finish up by testing the failover to make sure everything's working as expected.

trans-unit.source: Before you start
trans-unit.target: Before you start

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have these prerequisites in place:
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have these prerequisites in place:

trans-unit.source: You'll need a <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title></link> account.
trans-unit.target: You'll need a <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title></link> account.

trans-unit.source: You'll need a <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title></link> account.
trans-unit.target: You'll need a <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title></link> account.

trans-unit.source: You can start with a <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can start with a <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you can read about <link><linkText>Azure Site Recovery Manager pricing</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you can read about <link><linkText>Azure Site Recovery Manager pricing</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You'll need a VMM server in the primary and secondary sites running on System Center 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: You'll need a VMM server in the primary and secondary sites running on System Center 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: Each VMM server should have at least one cloud that contains:
trans-unit.target: Each VMM server should have at least one cloud that contains:

trans-unit.source: One or more VMM host groups.
trans-unit.target: One or more VMM host groups.

trans-unit.source: One or more Hyper-V host servers or clusters in each host group .
trans-unit.target: One or more Hyper-V host servers or clusters in each host group .

trans-unit.source: One or more virtual machines on the source Hyper-V server.
trans-unit.target: One or more virtual machines on the source Hyper-V server.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about setting up VMM clouds:
trans-unit.target: Learn more about setting up VMM clouds:

trans-unit.source: One or more Hyper-V servers running at least Windows Server 2012 with Hyper-V role with the latest updates installed.
trans-unit.target: One or more Hyper-V servers running at least Windows Server 2012 with Hyper-V role with the latest updates installed.

trans-unit.source: The server or cluster must be included in a VMM cloud.
trans-unit.target: The server or cluster must be included in a VMM cloud.

trans-unit.source: If you're running Hyper-V in a cluster note that cluster broker isn't created automatically if you have a static IP address-based cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you're running Hyper-V in a cluster note that cluster broker isn't created automatically if you have a static IP address-based cluster.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to configure the cluster broker manually.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to configure the cluster broker manually.

trans-unit.source: For instructions see <link><linkText>Configure Hyper-V Replica Broker</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions see <link><linkText>Configure Hyper-V Replica Broker</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You'll needed Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You'll needed Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you're running Azure PowerShell version 0.9.6 or later.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you're running Azure PowerShell version 0.9.6 or later.

trans-unit.source: Read <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Read <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Installing Azure PowerShell installs a customized console.
trans-unit.target: Installing Azure PowerShell installs a customized console.

trans-unit.source: You can run the PowerShell commands from this console or from any other host program, such as Windows PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: You can run the PowerShell commands from this console or from any other host program, such as Windows PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Set up PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Set up PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Open a PowerShell console and run this command to switch to the ARM module:
trans-unit.target: Open a PowerShell console and run this command to switch to the ARM module:

trans-unit.source: Switch-AzureMode AzureResourceManager
trans-unit.target: Switch-AzureMode AzureResourceManager

trans-unit.source: Now run this command to add your Azure account to the PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Now run this command to add your Azure account to the PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet prompts you for login credentials for your account.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet prompts you for login credentials for your account.

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureAccount
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureAccount

trans-unit.source: Note that if you're a CSP partner working on behalf of a tenant you'll need to specify the customer as a tenant when you add the Azure account:
trans-unit.target: Note that if you're a CSP partner working on behalf of a tenant you'll need to specify the customer as a tenant when you add the Azure account:

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureAccount-Tenant "customer"
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureAccount-Tenant "customer"

trans-unit.source: An account can have several subscriptions so you'll need to associate the subscription you want to use with the account.
trans-unit.target: An account can have several subscriptions so you'll need to associate the subscription you want to use with the account.

trans-unit.source: Select-AzureSubscription -SubscriptionName $SubscriptionName
trans-unit.target: Select-AzureSubscription -SubscriptionName $SubscriptionName

trans-unit.source: If you're using Site Recovery cmdlets for the first time in the subscription, you need to register the Azure provider for Site Recovery:
trans-unit.target: If you're using Site Recovery cmdlets for the first time in the subscription, you need to register the Azure provider for Site Recovery:

trans-unit.source: Register-AzureProvider -ProviderNamespace Microsoft.SiteRecovery
trans-unit.target: Register-AzureProvider -ProviderNamespace Microsoft.SiteRecovery

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Set up the Site Recovery vault
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Set up the Site Recovery vault

trans-unit.source: If you haven't currently got a Site Recovery vault you'll need to create one by running the <link><linkText>New-AzureSiteRecoveryVault</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: If you haven't currently got a Site Recovery vault you'll need to create one by running the <link><linkText>New-AzureSiteRecoveryVault</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: `New-AzureSiteRecoveryVault -Location $VaultGeo -Name $VaultName;
trans-unit.target: `New-AzureSiteRecoveryVault -Location $VaultGeo -Name $VaultName;

trans-unit.source: $vault = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVault -Name $VaultName;`
trans-unit.target: $vault = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVault -Name $VaultName;`

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Generate a vault registration key
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Generate a vault registration key

trans-unit.source: Run the <link><linkText>Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to get a vault registration key.
trans-unit.target: Run the <link><linkText>Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to get a vault registration key.

trans-unit.source: You need this key to register VMM servers in the vault:
trans-unit.target: You need this key to register VMM servers in the vault:

trans-unit.source: $VaultSettingsFile = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile -Location $VaultGeo -Name $VaultName -Path $OutputPathForSettingsFile;
trans-unit.target: $VaultSettingsFile = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile -Location $VaultGeo -Name $VaultName -Path $OutputPathForSettingsFile;

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Install the Azure Site Recovery Provider
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Install the Azure Site Recovery Provider

trans-unit.source: Download the Provider installation file from the Quick Start page in the Site Recovery vault.
trans-unit.target: Download the Provider installation file from the Quick Start page in the Site Recovery vault.

trans-unit.source: On each VMM server create a folder using this command:
trans-unit.target: On each VMM server create a folder using this command:

trans-unit.source: pushd C:\ASR\
trans-unit.target: pushd C:\ASR\

trans-unit.source: Run this command to extract the files from the downloaded Provider:
trans-unit.target: Run this command to extract the files from the downloaded Provider:

trans-unit.source: `AzureSiteRecoveryProvider.exe /x:.
trans-unit.target: `AzureSiteRecoveryProvider.exe /x:.

trans-unit.source: Install the provider by running:
trans-unit.target: Install the provider by running:

trans-unit.source: .\SetupDr.exe /i
trans-unit.target: .\SetupDr.exe /i

trans-unit.source: `$installationRegPath = "hklm:\software\Microsoft\Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager Server\DRAdapter"
trans-unit.target: `$installationRegPath = "hklm:\software\Microsoft\Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager Server\DRAdapter"

trans-unit.source: do
trans-unit.target: do

trans-unit.source: $isNotInstalled = $true;
trans-unit.target: $isNotInstalled = $true;

trans-unit.source: if(Test-Path $installationRegPath)
trans-unit.target: if(Test-Path $installationRegPath)

trans-unit.source: $isNotInstalled = $false;
trans-unit.target: $isNotInstalled = $false;

trans-unit.source: }While($isNotInstalled)`
trans-unit.target: }While($isNotInstalled)`

trans-unit.source: Wait for the installation to finish and then register the server in the vault:
trans-unit.target: Wait for the installation to finish and then register the server in the vault:

trans-unit.source: `$BinPath = $env:SystemDrive+"\Program Files\Microsoft System Center 2012 R2\Virtual Machine Manager\bin"
trans-unit.target: `$BinPath = $env:SystemDrive+"\Program Files\Microsoft System Center 2012 R2\Virtual Machine Manager\bin"

trans-unit.source: pushd $BinPath
trans-unit.target: pushd $BinPath

trans-unit.source: $encryptionFilePath = "C:\temp\"
trans-unit.target: $encryptionFilePath = "C:\temp\"

trans-unit.source: .\DRConfigurator.exe /r /Credentials $VaultSettingFilePath /vmmfriendlyname $env:COMPUTERNAME /dataencryptionenabled $encryptionFilePath /startvmmservice`
trans-unit.target: .\DRConfigurator.exe /r /Credentials $VaultSettingFilePath /vmmfriendlyname $env:COMPUTERNAME /dataencryptionenabled $encryptionFilePath /startvmmservice`

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Set up the vault context
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Set up the vault context

trans-unit.source: Run the Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVault cmdlet to make sure all commands run under the specific vault:
trans-unit.target: Run the Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVault cmdlet to make sure all commands run under the specific vault:

trans-unit.source: $Vault = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVault -ResouceGroupName $ResourceGroupName | where { $_.Name -eq $VaultName}
trans-unit.target: $Vault = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVault -ResouceGroupName $ResourceGroupName | where { $_.Name -eq $VaultName}

trans-unit.source: Download the vault settings:
trans-unit.target: Download the vault settings:

trans-unit.source: $VaultSettingsFile = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile -Vault $Vault -Path $OutputPathForSettingsFile
trans-unit.target: $VaultSettingsFile = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile -Vault $Vault -Path $OutputPathForSettingsFile

trans-unit.source: To make sure the cmdlets run under the vault run:
trans-unit.target: To make sure the cmdlets run under the vault run:

trans-unit.source: Import-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile -Path $VaultSetingsFile.FilePath
trans-unit.target: Import-AzureSiteRecoveryVaultSettingsFile -Path $VaultSetingsFile.FilePath

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Configure cloud protection settings
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Configure cloud protection settings

trans-unit.source: After the VMM server is registered in the vault you can configure cloud protection settings that will be applied to all virtual machines on Hyper-V hosts located in clouds on registered VMM server.
trans-unit.target: After the VMM server is registered in the vault you can configure cloud protection settings that will be applied to all virtual machines on Hyper-V hosts located in clouds on registered VMM server.

trans-unit.source: Create a container in the vault for the primary and secondary clouds:
trans-unit.target: Create a container in the vault for the primary and secondary clouds:

trans-unit.source: $PrimaryContainer = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionContainer -FriendlyName $PrimaryCloudName
trans-unit.target: $PrimaryContainer = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionContainer -FriendlyName $PrimaryCloudName

trans-unit.source: $$RecoveryContainer = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionContainer -FriendlyName $RecoveryCloudName
trans-unit.target: $$RecoveryContainer = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionContainer -FriendlyName $RecoveryCloudName

trans-unit.source: Configure protection settings to apply to the clouds:
trans-unit.target: Configure protection settings to apply to the clouds:

trans-unit.source: New-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionProfile -Name $ProtectionProfileName -ReplicationProvider HyperVReplica -ReplicationMethod Online -ReplicationFrequencyInSeconds 30 -RecoveryPoints 1 -ApplicationConsistentSnapshotFrequencyInHours 0 -ReplicationPort 8083 -Authentication Kerberos -AllowReplicaDeletion
trans-unit.target: New-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionProfile -Name $ProtectionProfileName -ReplicationProvider HyperVReplica -ReplicationMethod Online -ReplicationFrequencyInSeconds 30 -RecoveryPoints 1 -ApplicationConsistentSnapshotFrequencyInHours 0 -ReplicationPort 8083 -Authentication Kerberos -AllowReplicaDeletion

trans-unit.source: Start a job to associate the cloud containers with the cloud protection settings:
trans-unit.target: Start a job to associate the cloud containers with the cloud protection settings:

trans-unit.source: Start-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionProfileAssociationJob -ProtectionProfile $ProtectionProfile -PrimaryProtectionContainer $PrimaryContainer -RecoveryProtectionContainer $RecoveryContainer
trans-unit.target: Start-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionProfileAssociationJob -ProtectionProfile $ProtectionProfile -PrimaryProtectionContainer $PrimaryContainer -RecoveryProtectionContainer $RecoveryContainer

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Enable VM protection
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Enable VM protection

trans-unit.source: Enable protection for VMs in the VMM clouds:
trans-unit.target: Enable protection for VMs in the VMM clouds:

trans-unit.source: Get the VM you want to protect:
trans-unit.target: Get the VM you want to protect:

trans-unit.source: $VM = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionEntity -ProtectionContainer $PrimaryContainer -FriendlyName $VMName
trans-unit.target: $VM = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionEntity -ProtectionContainer $PrimaryContainer -FriendlyName $VMName

trans-unit.source: Enable protection for the VM:
trans-unit.target: Enable protection for the VM:

trans-unit.source: Set-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionEntity -ProtectionEntity $VM -Protection Enable
trans-unit.target: Set-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionEntity -ProtectionEntity $VM -Protection Enable

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Run a test failover
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Run a test failover

trans-unit.source: Select the VM you want to fail over:
trans-unit.target: Select the VM you want to fail over:

trans-unit.source: $VM = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionEntity -ProtectionContainer $PrimaryContainer -FriendlyName $VMName
trans-unit.target: $VM = Get-AzureSiteRecoveryProtectionEntity -ProtectionContainer $PrimaryContainer -FriendlyName $VMName

trans-unit.source: Run a test failover job:
trans-unit.target: Run a test failover job:

trans-unit.source: $ currentJob = Start-AzureSiteRecoveryTestFailoverJob -ProtectionEntity $VM -Direction PrimaryToRecovery
trans-unit.target: $ currentJob = Start-AzureSiteRecoveryTestFailoverJob -ProtectionEntity $VM -Direction PrimaryToRecovery

trans-unit.source: Check that the failed over VM appears in the secondary site and complete the failover:
trans-unit.target: Check that the failed over VM appears in the secondary site and complete the failover:

trans-unit.source: Resume-AzureSiteRecoveryJob -Id $currentJob.Name
trans-unit.target: Resume-AzureSiteRecoveryJob -Id $currentJob.Name

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For questions and comments on this scenario visit the <link><linkText>Site Recovery forum</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For questions and comments on this scenario visit the <link><linkText>Site Recovery forum</linkText><title></title></link>
